parallel
Class FasterParallelAsynchBatchPriorityTaskExecutor

java.lang.Object
  parallel.FasterParallelAsynchBatchPriorityTaskExecutor
public final class FasterParallelAsynchBatchPriorityTaskExecutor
extends java.lang.Object

A faster class that implements thread-pooling to allow its users to execute concurrently batch of tasks implementing the ComparableTaskObject interface. The run() method of each task must clearly be thread-safe!, and also, after calling executeBatch(tasks), no thread (including the one in which the call originated) should manipulate in any way the submitted tasks or their container (the Collection argument to the call). Unfortunately, there is no mechanism in the language to enforce this constraint; the user of the library has to enforce this (mild) constraint in their code. The class utilizes the (faster) Message-Passing mechanism implemented in the SimplePriorityMsgPassingCoordinator class of this package. The class itself is thread-safe meaning that there can exist multiple FasterParallelAsynchBatchPriorityTaskExecutor objects, multiple concurrent threads may call the public methods of the class on the same or different objects as long as the constraints mentioned above are satisfied.

Title: popt4jlib

Description: A Parallel Meta-Heuristic Optimization Library in Java

Copyright: Copyright (c) 2011

Company:

Version:
1.0
Author:
Ioannis T. Christou

executeBatch

public void executeBatch(java.util.Collection tasks)
                  throws ParallelException,
                         ParallelExceptionUnsubmittedTasks
the main method of the class. Submits all tasks in the argument collection (must be objects implementing the ComparableTaskObject interface in package parallel) for execution, and the thread-pool will ignore any exceptions any task may throw when its run() method is invoked. The call is asynchronous, so that the method does return immediately without waiting for any task to complete; however, if all threads in the thread-pool are busy and the FasterParallelAsynchBatchPriorityTaskExecutor was constructed via the single-argument constructor, or the second argument in the two-argument constructor was true, then the next task executes in the current thread. The call will also block in case the queue of tasks in the thread-pool (implemented in SimplePriorityMsgPassingCoordinator class of this package) is full (default=10000) in which case the current thread will wait until threads in the thread-pool finish up their tasks so the queue becomes less than full and can accept more tasks. Notice the possibility for locking when tasks sent to this executor are dependent upon latter tasks to be submitted to the same executor, but the executor becomes full (only possible because of the finite capacity of the executor's thread-pool). The application must ensure this situation does not happen (the executor cannot do anything to prevent this). See also the discussion in parallel.DynamicAsynchTaskExecutor. A synchronous version is implemented in the ParallelBatchTaskExecutor class.

Parameters:
tasks - Collection a Collection of ComparableTaskObject objects
Throws:
ParallelException - if the shutDown() method has been called prior to this call
ParallelExceptionUnSubmittedTasks - if this object does not allow running tasks in the current thread and some tasks could not be sent to the thread-pool due to a full SimplePriorityMsgPassingCoordinator msg-queue; in this case the unsubmitted tasks are returned inside the exception object.
ParallelExceptionUnsubmittedTasks

execute

public boolean execute(ComparableTaskObject task)
                throws ParallelException
executes in one of the threads in the thread-pool of this executor the task argument. The task will never run on the current thread.

Parameters:
task - ComparableTaskObject
Returns:
boolean true iff the task was successfully submitted.
Throws:
ParallelException - if the executor is not running

shutDown

public void shutDown()
              throws ParallelException,
                     ParallelExceptionUnsubmittedTasks
shut-down all the threads in this executor's thread-pool. It is the caller's responsibility to ensure that after this method has been called no other thread (including the threads in the thread-pool) won't call the executeBatch() method. Use of condition-counters or similar (e.g. as in the class graph.AllMWCFinderBKMT) may be necessary when tasks given to the thread-pool for execution may call the executeBatch() method recursively. The executor cannot be used afterwards, and will throw ParallelException if the method executeBatch() or shutDown() is called again.

Throws:
ParallelException
java.lang.InterruptedException
ParallelExceptionUnsubmittedTasks
